prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. What is the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$?
solution: We know that $4^{4}>123_{10}>4^{3}$. So, we can tell that $123_{10}$ in base four will have four digits. $4^{3}=64$, which can go into 123 only one time at most, leaving $123-1\cdot64 = 59$ for the next three digits. $4^{2}=16$ goes into 59 three times at most, leaving us with $59-3\cdot16 = 11$. Then, $4^{1}=4$ goes into 11 two times at most, leaving $11-2\cdot4 = 3$ for the ones digit. All together, the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$ is $\boxed{1323_{4}}$.
gpt_response:
To find the base four equivalent of the decimal number $123_{10}$, we need to divide it successively by 4 and keep track of the remainders. 

First, $123$ divided by 4 gives a quotient of 30 and a remainder of 3. So, the least significant digit in the base four representation will be 3.

Next, 30 divided by 4 gives a quotient of 7 and a remainder of 2. So, the next digit will be 2.

Finally, 7 divided by 4 gives a quotient of 1 and a remainder of 3. So, the most significant digit will be 1.

Putting all the remainders together in reverse order, we get the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$ as $1323_4$.

Next, 30 divided by 4 gives a quotient of 7 and a remainder of 2. So, the next digit will be 2.

Finally, 7 divided by 4 gives a quotient of 1 and a remainder of 3. So, the most significant digit will be 1.

Putting all the remainders together in reverse order, we get the base four equivalent of $123_{10}$ as $1323_4$.
